description:
Arabidopsis thaliana, commonly known as thale cress or mouse-ear cress, is a small flowering plant that belongs to the mustard family (Brassicaceae). It is a widely used model organism in plant biology and genetics due to its small genome size, rapid life cycle, and ease of cultivation.

Arabidopsis thaliana is an annual, herbaceous plant that typically grows to a height of 10-30 centimeters. It has a rosette of small, simple, and lobed leaves at the base, with small white flowers that develop into slender, elongated seed pods. The plant's life cycle can be completed in as little as 6 to 8 weeks under optimal conditions.

Arabidopsis thaliana has a diploid genome with 5 pairs of chromosomes, making it one of the smallest and most well-studied plant genomes. Its genome was the first to be sequenced among higher plants, providing valuable insights into plant genetics, development, and evolution.

This species is widely distributed across the northern hemisphere, found naturally in Europe, Asia, and North Africa. It is a popular choice for research due to its small size, short generation time, and the availability of a wide range of genetic resources and tools, including a well-annotated genome, extensive mutant collections, and a wide array of molecular and genomic techniques.

Arabidopsis thaliana has become a crucial model organism for understanding fundamental biological processes in plants, such as photosynthesis, flowering, and response to environmental stresses, and has significantly contributed to our understanding of plant biology and the development of new agricultural and biotechnological applications.
